triples.name: Echo chamber (media)
triples.relevance: The paper proposes a novel model to explain echo chamber formation and emergence in social networks.

triples.name: Social polarization
triples.relevance: The paper addresses the empirically observed phenomenon of opinion polarization in social media contexts.

triples.name: Social network
triples.relevance: Social networks provide the foundational structure within which the model simulates opinion dynamics and polarization.

triples.name: Misinformation
triples.relevance: The paper motivates its research by addressing concerns about misinformation spread through echo chambers.

triples.name: Opinion dynamics
triples.relevance: Opinion dynamics serves as the theoretical foundation for modeling how agents' opinions evolve through social interaction.

triples.name: Radicalization
triples.relevance: The paper proposes radicalization as a novel reinforcing mechanism driving evolution toward extreme opinions.

triples.name: Homophily
triples.relevance: Homophily is an empirical principle incorporated into the model to characterize heterogeneous agent interactions.

triples.name: Social influence
triples.relevance: Social influence is identified as a key mechanism governing the transition between consensus and polarized states.

triples.name: Twitter
triples.relevance: Twitter data provides empirical validation for the model's ability to reproduce observed patterns in real polarized debates.
